docs.lead_paragraph: Women whose sexual partners regularly use condoms can reduce by half their risk of developing pelvic inflammatory disease, a painful condition that can lead to infertility, according to a new study. Writing in the August issue of The American Journal of Public Health, researchers said their findings offered evidence that condoms, well established as barriers against viral infection, also help prevent the kinds of bacterial infection that can cause P.I.D., as the disease is known. The study was led by Dr. Roberta B. Ness of the University of Pittsburgh.
docs.abstract: Dr Roberta B Ness of University of Pittsburgh leads study on effectiveness of condoms in reducing occurrence of pelvic inflammatory disease in women; research, published in American Journal of Public Health, finds condom use helps prevent bacterial infections that cause PID, which affects about million American women each year (S)
docs.snippet: Women whose sexual partners regularly use condoms can reduce by half their risk of developing pelvic inflammatory disease, a painful condition that can lead to infertility, according to a new study.     Writing in the August issue of The American...

docs.lead_paragraph: Linked as it is to instances of insomnia, palpitations, hot flashes and outbursts of inexplicable anger and despair, menopause looms as one of the more bewildering stages in a woman's life. Its mystery is only enhanced by the fact that many women are not sure when it begins. For help in figuring that out, women can turn to over-the-counter menopause test kits, which have been on the market for the past few years. These are urine tests, similar to home pregnancy tests, but with names like Estroven, Menocheck and RU25 Plus. They are sold at drugstores for about $20.

headline.main: Over-the-Counter Menopause Test Kits Offer Few Answers

docs.abstract: Over-the-counter menopause test kits are now available for women wanting to know if symptoms of menopause are related or unrelated to menopausal stage; doctors, however, warn that results are unreliable, particularly for women who are experiencing perimenopause, and require tests and consultation with physician to truly identify if menopause has begun; menopause normally occurs between 42 and 58 years of age; stages of perimenopause, menopause and postmenopause described; common symptoms associated with menopause and potential treatments discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With a jangle of bracelets, Patricia Shelton slid her chair in front of the air-conditioner in her daughter's apartment and fluttered her hands to cool her face. ''I swear, some days it's the menopause that gets me, not the H.I.V.,'' she said.
docs.abstract: Number of Americans over 50 infected with HIV has quintupled since 1990; Dr Marcia G Ory, Texas A&M University public health professor and co-author of 2003 Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report on AIDS in older Americans, holds that majority of AIDS cases by 2010 will be in people over 50; challenges that are specific to older Americans and their infection, such as isolation, economic hardships, other medical concerns and lagging prevention programs, discussed; studies show that overall older persons with AIDS are relatively optimistic; graph; photo (L)

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: An obese Massachusetts woman and her 8-month-old fetus died of complications 18 months after the woman had stomach-stapling surgery, an apparent first that is leading to warnings about the risks of pregnancy soon after the surgery. The deaths, in 2002, raise concerns because most of the 110,000 people who have gastric, or stomach, bypass surgery each year in the United States are women in their child-bearing years, say doctors at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston who tried to save the woman and fetus. They reported on the case in a letter in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine.

headline.main: Case Offers Caution on Stomach-Stapling Surgery

docs.abstract: Article on case involving extremely obese Massachusetts woman and her eight-month-old fetus who died from complications of gastric bypass surgery; deaths raise concerns because most of estimated 110,000 people who will have gastric bypass surgery this year are women of child-bearing age; one in five bypass patients may suffer complications from surgery, but other research shows lower rates of pregnancy complications after weight loss surgery (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: JOURNAL OF THE DEAD: A Story of Friendship and Murder in the New Mexico Desert, by Jason Kersten. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $12.95.) In the summer of 1999, two friends from the Boston area wandered into sun-blasted Carlsbad Caverns National Park with three pints of water between them and got lost; when a ranger found them four days later, one was badly dehydrated, the other stabbed to death by his friend. The mystery is why he was killed. This ''ruminative, wholly absorbing'' account unfolds with ''quiet authority, lending unexpected dignity to the whole affair,'' our reviewer, Bruce Barcott, wrote in the Book Review last year. THE GREAT WAVE: Gilded Age Misfits, Japanese Eccentrics, and the Opening of Old Japan, by Christopher Benfey. (Random House, $14.95.) In the years after Commodore Perry hit the shores of Japan in 1853, new perceptions took hold among American and Japanese artists, thinkers and writers, a cultural give-and-take that still echoes today. Benfey ''brings to his subject a scholar's thoroughness, a critic's astuteness and a storyteller's sense of drama,'' William Deresiewicz said here in 2003. The result is a ''symphony not only of characters but of ideas.'' EARLY OCCULT MEMORY SYSTEMS OF THE LOWER MIDWEST, by B. H. Fairchild. (Norton, $13.95.) Winner of a National Book Critics Circle Award, this collection of poetry resonates with loneliness as it conjures history writ large and small in the plains and small towns of the Midwest. The poems display ''the American voice at its best: confident and conflicted, celebratory and melancholic,'' Michael Hainey wrote in these pages last year. LIARS AND SAINTS, by Maile Meloy. (Scribner, $13.) In this first novel, the fortunes of four generations of a Roman Catholic family in Southern California are wrapped up in a family secret: the matriarch tries to conceal the unwanted pregnancy of her teenage daughter by pretending the baby is actually hers, a ruse that requires delicate planning, to say the least. The result is a ''spectacular'' book that ''explores religion and faith from nearly every possible angle, with equal empathy for the faithful and doubting alike,'' Sara Mosle said here in 2003. THE PRINCE OF PROVIDENCE: The Rise and Fall of Buddy Cianci, America's Most Notorious Mayor, by Mike Stanton. (Random House, $14.95.) Coarse, profane and funny (often at the same time), the larger-than-life Cianci lorded over Providence, R.I., for more than 20 years, running a brazen criminal enterprise of kickbacks, shakedowns and threats before landing in jail in 2002. Last year our reviewer, Clyde Haberman, found this a flawed account, but one with ''impressive'' reportage and ''great yarns.'' THE HILLS AT HOME, by Nancy Clark. (Anchor, $14.95.) This first novel, about an extended WASP family gathered under the roof of a rambling, 200-year-old clapboard home in New England, is filled with the haphazard encounters that make up domestic life and the inflections of opinionated people who share meals, territory and belongings with uneasy familiarity. Clark's ''graceful, intelligent and very funny'' book ''reminds us that the tribe has not vanished, and that we're all members of it,'' Roxana Robinson said in these pages in 2003. It ''succeeds brilliantly'' in its ''revelation of a particular kind of life.'' A HOLE IN THE HEART, by Christopher Marquis. (St. Martin's Griffin, $13.95.) Bean Jessup, the frumpy protagonist of this first novel by a Times correspondent, opens up to the beauty of Alaska when she falls in love and marries a carpenter in a fishing town; after disaster strikes, she perseveres with the help of her husband's kleptomaniac mother and the two head to San Francisco, and a new life. The message? ''Loving good people and losing them: that's life,'' Bruce Barcott wrote here in 2003. THE LANDSCAPE OF HISTORY: How Historians Map the Past, by John Lewis Gaddis. (Oxford University, $13.95.) Drawing on a series of lectures he gave at Oxford, a Yale professor explores the relationship between science and history. In 2002 in these pages, Alan Brinkley found this ''a bold and challenging book'' that ''provides a strong statement for our time of both the limits and the value of the historical enterprise.'' Scott Veale

docs.lead_paragraph: Tara Strong -- often wears jeans or gym clothes to work, but no one minds. That is because she is a voice actor, putting words into the mouths of cartoon characters like Bubbles in ''The Powerpuff Girls,'' Dil Pickles in ''Rugrats'' and Lil' Red in ''Shrek 2.'' ''I usually have 10 different animation projects going at a time,'' said Ms. Strong, 31, whose current roles include Raven in ''Teen Titans'' and Timmy Turner in ''The FairlyOdd Parents.'' Keeping all the voices straight is easy, she said, but creating them can be tricky. ''Writers will ask me to make someone a year older, or to give them buck teeth,'' she said.
docs.abstract: Tara Strong, voice actor who works in animated films and television shows, talks about clothes she likes to wear; photo (S)
